extraction_metadata.article_title: Economics of open source library software: evidences from Indian libraries

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Open Source Software (OSS) business model - A collaborative software development model where software is developed by users and for users, primarily based on altruism and collaborative development without proprietary rights, following a 'bazaar' style of development.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Open-source software (OSS) is a new way of developing software, which is primarily developed by the users and for the users.' | Page 3: 'OSS espouses a philosophy where collaborative development and sharing are inextricably intertwined.' | Page 3: 'First, the OSS movement took off through the activity of a community that did not follow profit motivations, but it is based on altruism. Second, a hierarchical coordination emerged sans proprietary rights, i.e. bazaar style of development.'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Open-source software (OSS)' | Page 3: 'OSS phenomenon has metamorphosed into a more mainstream and commercially viable form, which Fitzgerald (2006) labels as OSS 2.0.' | Page 2: 'OSS is viewed as: /C15technology meant for a common cause; /C15a powerful force for good; /C15a public good'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The purpose of this paper is to study the adoption and use of open source software (OSS) in the libraries of Institutions of National Importance (INIs) in India' | Page 1: 'This paper is the first of its kind that explores the economic impact of OSS on the adopting libraries'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the target customer type of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Institutions of National Importance (INIs) in India' | Page 8: 'The results of the study show that university libraries of India could save an estimated Rs 417m by adopting open source ILS'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the typical size of offering companies that adopt this software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Mixed size organizations - from small service providers to large established companies
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 13: 'There are many companies that are floated around these products, namely, ByWater Solutions, LibLime for Koha and Red Hat for Red Hat Linux have large developer communities to support them. Besides, many companies such as Informatics, OSS Labs and OpenLX increase their profits through cost savings'

extracted_data.question_text: In which geographic region was the software business model presented in the article studied or applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Economics of open source library software: evidences from Indian libraries' | Page 1: 'The purpose of this paper is to study the adoption and use of open source software (OSS) in the libraries of Institutions of National Importance (INIs) in India'

extracted_data.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Indian Institute of Technology (IITs) and National Institute of Technology (NITs) libraries
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'This study presents a holistic picture of the 38 libraries of IITs and National Institute of Technology (NIT). Out of 38 libraries, 42.1 per cent (n= 16) were from IITs and 57.9 per cent (n= 22) from NITs'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of product or service offered by the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The findings of the study reveal that the libraries of INIs adopt and use OSS in integrated library system (ILS) (18.4 per cent), digital repository (95.2 per cent) and library website (65.5 per cent)'

extracted_data.question_text: How is the software delivered or deployed in the business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 11: 'As the OSS is available for freely downloadable, there is low product risk for the library. It can be downloaded and have a trial run in the library' | Page 13: 'They provide installation services, conversion services, configuration and customisation, training and technical support'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the intellectual property regime adopted by the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Open-source software (OSS) is a new way of developing software, which is primarily developed by the users and for the users' | Page 3: 'OSS espouses a philosophy where collaborative development and sharing are inextricably intertwined'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there specific restrictions or compatibilities of licensing mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: No licensing restrictions mentioned - software is freely downloadable and usable
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 11: 'As the OSS is available for freely downloadable, there is low product risk for the library. It can be downloaded and have a trial run in the library, besides evaluating all the features'

extracted_data.question_text: What are the revenue sources of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 13: 'Earnings from service are the main source of revenue for these types of companies such as Red Hat, who earns its revenue by facilitating technical supports and services' | Page 13: 'They provide installation services, conversion services, configuration and customisation, training and technical support. They earn their revenue from service only'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the base unit for pricing of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 13: 'They earn their revenue from service only and their business model is illustrated in Figure 2' | Page 13: 'As selling of OSS cannot sustain a business, these companies make a bundle of library products and services and up-sell it to existing major libraries'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the price presentation structure of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 11: 'As the OSS is available for freely downloadable' | Page 13: 'As selling of OSS cannot sustain a business, these companies make a bundle of library products and services and up-sell it to existing major libraries'

extracted_data.question_text: What currency and billing periodicity are used in the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: information not found in text

extracted_data.question_text: What is the role of the offering company in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 13: 'There are many third-party service providers to facilitate the OSS to the library' | Page 13: 'There are many companies who support and provide services on open source library software around the world'

extracted_data.question_text: What type of network effect is present in the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'OSS espouses a philosophy where collaborative development and sharing are inextricably intertwined. Thousands of top-notched programmers and hackers freely produce highly qualified software' | Page 2: 'OSS development model produces better and cheaper software than proprietary development model, and these are of high quality and sustainable software'

extracted_data.question_text: What are the customer acquisition channels of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 11: 'It can be downloaded and have a trial run in the library, besides evaluating all the features. If it deems fit, then it can be adopted in the library' | Page 13: 'There are many third-party service providers to facilitate the OSS to the library'

extracted_data.question_text: Does the software business model presented in the article use cloud marketplaces or platforms?
extracted_data.source_citation: information not found in text

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Low cost, vendor lock-in avoidance, experimentation freedom
Customer Segment: Academic libraries, educational institutions
Revenue Streams: Service-based revenue from support, training, implementation
Key Activities: Software development, community building, service provision
Cost Structure: Community-based development reduces development costs
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 11: 'The most important intangible benefit of the open source library software is that it is tested and evaluated whether they meet the requirements like that of PS' | Page 12: 'The total cost of ownership (TCO) of open source library software, for example, in case of ILS software Koha or Evergreen will be quite lower than their proprietary counterpart' | Page 13: 'Earnings from service are the main source of revenue for these types of companies'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_data.extracted_value:
Producers of Open Source Library Software (e.g. Koha.org, Dspace) | Software Development | Provides free software to libraries | Collaborates with service providers
Libraries | End Users | Adopts free software, pays for services | Receives support from service providers
Service Providers (e.g. Bywater Solutions, LibLime, Informatics) | Support Services | Provides paid services to libraries | Partners with software producers
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 14: 'Producers of Open Source Library Software (e.g. Koha.org, Dspace) → Libraries (Free) → Service Providers (e.g. Bywater Solutions, LibLime, Informatics) (Free Service Charges)' | Page 13: 'There are many third-party service providers to facilitate the OSS to the library. In the context of library, they provide installation services, conversion services, configuration and customisation, training and technical support'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'OSS offers a viable and strong alternative to proprietary software (PS) and has larger economic implication when it is adopted in any enterprises including libraries' | Page 11: 'OSS encourages LIS professionals to experiment with new software in the library, acquire new knowledge and create new services' | Page 12: 'The total cost of ownership (TCO) of open source library software will be quite lower than their proprietary counterpart'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Institutional policy on OSS adoption → Higher adoption rates
Favoring OSS by institutions → Increased implementation
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 10: 'The results of Pearson chi-square also indicate that there is a statistically significant association between the institutions having OSS adoption policy and preferred type ILS used' | Page 3: 'Thousands of top-notched programmers and hackers freely produce highly qualified software' | Page 13: 'To have a high-quality service, the library should have internal technical staff or seek service from different companies/individual experts'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Technical staff or external service providers → Implementation and maintenance
Institutional OSS adoption policy → Organizational support
Internet connectivity → Software download and updates
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 13: 'To have a high-quality service, the library should have internal technical staff or seek service from different companies/individual experts' | Page 10: 'To increase the adoption of OSS in the library, the institute should consider having OSS adoption policy' | Page 11: 'OSS encourages LIS professionals to experiment with new software in the library, acquire new knowledge'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Selling OSS cannot sustain a business → Revenue model limitations
Need for technical expertise → Implementation barriers
Cultural resistance to OSS → Adoption challenges
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 13: 'As selling of OSS cannot sustain a business, these companies make a bundle of library products and services and up-sell it to existing major libraries' | Page 4: 'Although there are certain bottlenecks of adopting OSS in libraries, these are social (cultural) disparity, conceptual confusions, digital divide and lack of technological, financial and human development'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Social and cultural resistance to OSS adoption
Lack of technological, financial and human development
Need for technical expertise for implementation
Revenue sustainability challenges for service providers
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'Although there are certain bottlenecks of adopting OSS in libraries, these are social (cultural) disparity, conceptual confusions, digital divide and lack of technological, financial and human development' | Page 13: 'As selling of OSS cannot sustain a business, these companies make a bundle of library products and services'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Institutional OSS adoption policies → Addresses cultural resistance and provides organizational support
Service provider ecosystem → Provides technical expertise and implementation support
Training programs → Builds human development and technical capabilities
Community-based development → Ensures quality and sustainability
Bundled service offerings → Addresses revenue sustainability for providers
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 10: 'To increase the adoption of OSS in the library, the institute should consider having OSS adoption policy' | Page 13: 'There are many third-party service providers to facilitate the OSS to the library' | Page 11: 'OSS encourages LIS professionals to experiment with new software in the library, acquire new knowledge and create new services'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value:
Metric; Value; Unit; Period; Method; Source
Adoption rate ILS; 18.4; per cent; Study period; Survey; 38 INI libraries
Adoption rate digital repository; 95.2; per cent; Study period; Survey; 38 INI libraries
Adoption rate library website; 34.5; per cent; Study period; Survey; 29 libraries with websites
Potential savings; 417; million INR; Projected; Calculation; All university libraries in India
Cost comparison ILS; 0-1.5; million INR; Current; Market analysis; OSS vs proprietary software
Cost comparison digital repository; 0-1.0; million INR; Current; Market analysis; OSS vs proprietary software
Cost comparison CMS; 0-0.5; million INR; Current; Market analysis; OSS vs proprietary software
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The findings of the study reveal that the libraries of INIs adopt and use OSS in integrated library system (ILS) (18.4 per cent), digital repository (95.2 per cent) and library website (65.5 per cent)' | Page 8: 'The results of the study show that university libraries of India could save an estimated Rs 417m by adopting open source ILS such as Koha, Evergreen, NewGenLib and ABCD' | Page 11: 'Software OSS cost PS cost (in INR) ILS 0 0.05-1.5m digital repository 0 0.05-1.0m CMS 0 0.05-0.5m LMS 0 0.05-2.0m'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the temporal period and maturity of the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Received 21 April 2018, Revised 19 November 2018, Accepted 29 November 2018' | Page 8: 'The result shows that the use and adoption of OSS in libraries is an increasing trend' | Page 3: 'OSS phenomenon has metamorphosed into a more mainstream and commercially viable form, which Fitzgerald (2006) labels as OSS 2.0'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of evidence presented in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'To study the adoption and use of OSS, an online survey method was used as the population is widely distributed geographically around all INIs in India' | Page 5: 'Descriptive statistics and Pearson's chi-square are used in this study'

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?
extracted_value: Koha → Open source ILS mentioned as most favored
DSpace → Digital repository software with 95.2% adoption
Drupal → CMS used for library websites
Joomla! → CMS used for library websites
ByWater Solutions → Service provider for Koha
Red Hat → Example of service-based revenue model
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Koha, DSpace, Drupal and Joomla! are the most favoured OSS among the libraries of INIs' | Page 13: 'Amongst them, LibLime, Bywater Solutions, Equinox Software and Media Flex are popular service providers in open source ILS' | Page 13: 'Earnings from service are the main source of revenue for these types of companies such as Red Hat, who earns its revenue by facilitating technical supports and services'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: OSS 2.0 → More mainstream and commercially viable form with bazaar metaphor shifted to product delivery and support process
Service-based OSS model → Companies providing support, training, and implementation services
Community-driven OSS model → Traditional collaborative development approach
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'OSS phenomenon has metamorphosed into a more mainstream and commercially viable form, which Fitzgerald (2006) labels as OSS 2.0. He discusses how the bazaar metaphor, which is up to now has been associated with the OSS development process, has been actually shifted to become a metaphor better suited to the OSS 2.0 product delivery and support process' | Page 13: 'There are many third-party service providers to facilitate the OSS to the library'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Continued growth in OSS adoption in libraries
Government policy formulation for OSS adoption
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 8: 'The result shows that the use and adoption of OSS in libraries is an increasing trend' | Page 10: 'In addition, the government should also formulate national policy on OSS adoption' | Page 3: 'The emergence of OSS accentuates the fundamental alteration of the basic ground rules in the software landscape, signifying the end of the proprietary-driven model that has prevailed for the past 20 years'
